repnme.cdata!:
From chaos to order : implementing
            high-capacity urban transport systems in Colombia

abstracts.cdata!:
In the past, Colombia faced urban
            transport problems that significantly lowered the quality of
            life of urban Colombians. Starting in the late 1990s, the
            programa nacional de transporte urbano helped transform
            Colombia's urban transport system. The approaches under
            this program are now considered international best practice
            and have been replicated by cities around the world to
            address the transportation challenges.

docna.cdata!:
From chaos to order : implementing
            high-capacity urban transport systems in Colombia

            implementing high-capacity urban transport systems in Colombia

abstracts.cdata!:
This Results Profile focuses on
            transport in Colombia. Public transportation in Colombia was
            traditionally perceived as inefficient, unsafe, and
            polluting. The streets of Colombian cities were crowded with
            obsolete buses which operated with disregard for public
            safety and in near chaos, without organized bus stops. In
            1996, the government decided to create the Programa Nacional
            de Transporte Urbano supported by International Bank for
            Reconstruction and Development (IBRD) financing. The program
            centered its strategy on the development of Bus Rapid
            Transit (BRT), which achieves urban mobility at a fraction
            of the cost of rail systems. The most famous BRT system is
            Bogotá’s Transmilenio, conceptualized in 1998. Each day
            close to 1.4 million passengers, approximately 27 percent of
            the city’s public transport demand, benefitted from the
            Transmilenio in Bogotá. Riders of the two other complete BRT
            systems, Megabus, Pereira and Mio-Cali, have significantly
            improved their daily lives, benefiting from an organized,
            regulated, modern, and reliable public transportation system
            that utilizes a modern fleet and less polluting fuels. Since
            its inception, delegations from more than 20 countries have
            visited Colombia to learn about the program. Similarly,
            multi-city transport programs were being developed in other
            countries such as Mexico and Argentina with direct IBRD
            involvement and there had been a significant collaboration
            and sharing of knowledge between Colombia and other
            developing countries.

docna.cdata!: Implementación del transporte urbano en Colombia

abstracts.cdata!:
This Results Profile focuses on
            transport in Colombia. Public transportation in Colombia was
            traditionally perceived as inefficient, unsafe, and
            polluting. The streets of Colombian cities were crowded with
            obsolete buses which operated with disregard for public
            safety and in near chaos, without organized bus stops. In
            1996, the government decided to create the Programa Nacional
            de Transporte Urbano supported by International Bank for
            Reconstruction and Development (IBRD) financing. The program
            centered its strategy on the development of Bus Rapid
            Transit (BRT), which achieves urban mobility at a fraction
            of the cost of rail systems. The most famous BRT system is
            Bogotá’s Transmilenio, conceptualized in 1998. Each day
            close to 1.4 million passengers, approximately 27 percent of
            the city’s public transport demand, benefitted from the
            Transmilenio in Bogotá. Riders of the two other complete BRT
            systems, Megabus, Pereira and Mio-Cali, have significantly
            improved their daily lives, benefiting from an organized,
            regulated, modern, and reliable public transportation system
            that utilizes a modern fleet and less polluting fuels. Since
            its inception, delegations from more than 20 countries have
            visited Colombia to learn about the program. Similarly,
            multi-city transport programs were being developed in other
            countries such as Mexico and Argentina with direct IBRD
            involvement and there had been a significant collaboration
            and sharing of knowledge between Colombia and other
            developing countries.
